docs.snippet: Classroom Quotes      If you have ever been amused, annoyed or awed by something a professor said in class, ProfQuotes (www.profquotes.com) wants to know. This new site collects notable quotations credited to academics ranging from teaching assist...
docs.lead_paragraph: Classroom Quotes If you have ever been amused, annoyed or awed by something a professor said in class, ProfQuotes (www.profquotes.com) wants to know. This new site collects notable quotations credited to academics ranging from teaching assistants to famous scholars (''If we do not speak ill of the dead, who will?'' -- Harold Bloom).
docs.abstract: Online Diary column; ProfQuotes is Web site that collects and disseminates notable quotations credited to academics; photoblogs use diary format and are updated with original photos instead of commentary; SIBL Project Web site keeps track of popular songs inspired by literature; miscellaneous Web sites noted; drawings (M)

docs.snippet: ROGER S.H. SCHULMAN recalls being in the control room of a Hollywood sound studio as John Goodman, the actor, recorded the voice of Baloo the bear in ''The Jungle Book 2.'' As Mr. Goodman's voice resonated over a telephone line from a studio in Ne...
docs.lead_paragraph: ROGER S.H. SCHULMAN recalls being in the control room of a Hollywood sound studio as John Goodman, the actor, recorded the voice of Baloo the bear in ''The Jungle Book 2.'' As Mr. Goodman's voice resonated over a telephone line from a studio in New Orleans, a Disney executive turned to Mr. Schulman, one of the film's writers, to request additional dialogue for a roughhousing scene. But with the executive, Mr. Goodman, a dialogue director, engineers and others waiting in two studios, Mr. Schulman drew a blank. ''My brain just froze,'' he said. Trying to appear calm, Mr. Schulman quickly resorted to his black I.B.M. ThinkPad 240 notebook computer. He punched ''boxing'' into a word- and concept-association brainstorming program called IdeaFisher, going through the response ''fighting/fighting sports'' until he got to ''sticks and stones will break my bones.''

docs.snippet: Tom Glazer, a folk singer and songwriter best known for his whimsical children's songs -- particularly one about a mountain of spaghetti -- died on Friday at his home in Philadelphia. He was 88.    Along with Leadbelly, Woody Guthrie, Josh White a...
docs.lead_paragraph: Tom Glazer, a folk singer and songwriter best known for his whimsical children's songs -- particularly one about a mountain of spaghetti -- died on Friday at his home in Philadelphia. He was 88. Along with Leadbelly, Woody Guthrie, Josh White and Burl Ives, Mr. Glazer was a Big City folk singer, one of a loose coalition of performers who made folk music a national phenomenon in the 1940's, presaging its commercial popularity in the 1960's.
docs.abstract: Tom Glazer, folk singer and songwriter best known for his whimsical children's songs, dies at age 88; photo (M)

headline.main: Tom Glazer, Folk Singer, Is Dead at 88

docs.snippet: The accounting scandal at Royal Ahold has left thousands of its Dutch employees in debt to the company.    In the 1990's, rising stock markets bolstered the idea that employees and companies alike could benefit by encouraging workers to own signif...
docs.lead_paragraph: The accounting scandal at Royal Ahold has left thousands of its Dutch employees in debt to the company. In the 1990's, rising stock markets bolstered the idea that employees and companies alike could benefit by encouraging workers to own significant stakes in their businesses. The idea spread in the United States and across the Atlantic.
docs.abstract: Accounting scandal at Royal Ahold has left thousands of its Dutch employees in debt to company; Ahold in 1990's created program that encouraged workers in Netherlands not only to buy stock but allowed them to borrow money to do so; some 3,500 workes at Ahold and its Dutch subsidiaries, including supermarket chain Albert Heijn, took out loans in last decade to buy shares of fund that invested in Ahold stock, debt and other obligations; company's stock and bonds have plunged in value since company disclosed accounting problems (Market Place column) (M)

headline.main: Market Place; Royal Ahold Accounting Scandal Leaves Dutch Employees With Heavy Debts

byline.original: By GREGORY CROUCH with JENNIFER BAYOT

docs.snippet: A grim, gray and -- after 75 minutes -- gone film by Israel Adrián Caetano, ''Bolivia'' is a tough-minded though modestly told parable of life on the streets. At certain points -- when the mire of anger, poverty and xenophobia could seemingly tak...
docs.lead_paragraph: A grim, gray and -- after 75 minutes -- gone film by Israel Adrián Caetano, ''Bolivia'' is a tough-minded though modestly told parable of life on the streets. At certain points -- when the mire of anger, poverty and xenophobia could seemingly take place anywhere -- Mr. Caetano's work is most telling and gripping. At others, his cold hostility toward Argentina, where the film is actually set, couldn't be more specific. Bolivia is the homeland of the poker-faced immigrant Freddy (Freddy Flores), who accepts a job as a grill man at a tiny restaurant. He's hired illegally by the brusque Enrique (Enrique Liporace) and paid 15 pesos (about $4.75) a day. Just after the opening, a television blares away with a soccer game, in which the Bolivians are dismissed by an Argentine announcer. It's not enough that the team is crushing the Bolivians; the ugly nationalism is an extra cleat in the back. It turns out that this game is on at the restaurant, with its equally loud and chauvinistic customers.
docs.abstract: Elvis Mitchell reviews Israel Adrian Caetano film Bolivia (M)

headline.main: Resentment Festers At Ladder's Bottom Rung

docs.snippet: EVENTS    CULTURE COUNSELORS -- Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday the appointment of 21 members to the Cultural Affairs Advisory Commission. The body is mandated by the New York City Charter and advises the mayor, cultural affairs com...
docs.lead_paragraph: EVENTS CULTURE COUNSELORS -- Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday the appointment of 21 members to the Cultural Affairs Advisory Commission. The body is mandated by the New York City Charter and advises the mayor, cultural affairs commissioner and other city officials on cultural matters. The commission, with Agnes Gund, the president emerita of the Museum of Modern Art, as chairwoman, also serves as a working board to help the Cultural Affairs Department in assisting nonprofit cultural organizations. Among the members of the commission are the artist Chuck Close; Karen Brooks Hopkins, president of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, and Judith O. Rubin, chairwoman of Playwrights Horizons.
docs.abstract: Arts Briefing column; NYC Mayor Michael R Bloomberg has named 21 members to Cultural Affairs Advisory Commission; photos (M)

docs.snippet: Christopher Wheeldon's ''Carousel (a Dance)'' was originally announced as a a piece d'occasion. It was not scheduled to be performed again after its premiere at the New York City Ballet's November gala, part of the Richard Rodgers Centennial.    W...
docs.lead_paragraph: Christopher Wheeldon's ''Carousel (a Dance)'' was originally announced as a a piece d'occasion. It was not scheduled to be performed again after its premiere at the New York City Ballet's November gala, part of the Richard Rodgers Centennial. Wisdom triumphs over folly. Mr. Wheeldon's ballet was too terrific not to be seen again, and it was spliced into the start of the company's final week on Saturday night at the New York State Theater. There will be an additional performance on Friday, led again by Alexandra Ansanelli and Benjamin Millepied, who has replaced the injured Damian Woetzel from the original cast.
docs.abstract: Anna Kisselgoff reviews New York City Ballet performance of Carousel (a Dance), choreographed by Christopher Wheeldon; photo (M)

headline.main: Whiffs of 'Carousel' Perfume a Love Duet

docs.snippet: ''Flower Drum Song,'' a new version of the 1958 musical by Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein II, is to close after the matinee on March 16 at the Virginia Theater, 245 West 52nd Street, Manhattan. Directed and choreographed by Robert Longbotto...
docs.lead_paragraph: ''Flower Drum Song,'' a new version of the 1958 musical by Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein II, is to close after the matinee on March 16 at the Virginia Theater, 245 West 52nd Street, Manhattan. Directed and choreographed by Robert Longbottom, the show will have run for 172 regular performances and 26 previews.
docs.abstract: Rodgers and Hammerstein musical Flower Drum Song to close after 172 regular performances and 26 previews (S)

docs.snippet: Royal Ahold, the giant Dutch-based grocer and food distributor, said today that it had overstated its earnings by at least $500 million over the last two years. The company's chief executive and chief financial officer are resigning.    The proble...
docs.lead_paragraph: Royal Ahold, the giant Dutch-based grocer and food distributor, said today that it had overstated its earnings by at least $500 million over the last two years. The company's chief executive and chief financial officer are resigning. The problems at Ahold, whose American supermarkets, mostly in the Northeast, include the Stop & Shop, Bi-Lo, Giant and Tops chains, stunned investors, who bid the company's stock price down by more than 60 percent, wiping out more than $5 billion in market value. Stocks of companies with major stakes in Ahold, including Aegon, ING and Fortis, also fell sharply.
docs.abstract: Royal Ahold, giant Dutch-based grocer and food distributor, says it overstated its earnings by at least $500 million over last two years; chief financial officer Michael Meurs and chief executive Cees van der Hoeven will leave company once successors are named; investors bid company's stock price down by more than 60 percent, wiping out more than $5 billion in market value; developments at Ahold revive concerns that European accounting standards may be no better at preventing big accounting scandals than American standards; Ahold says problems it has uncovered are centered maninly on promotional payments by manufacturers to Ahold's US Foodservice subsidiary; charts; photos (M)

byline.original: By GREGORY CROUCH with SUZANNE KAPNER

docs.snippet: Roman Polanski won as best director tonight and his film ''The Pianist,'' about a Jewish musician living in the Warsaw ghetto, won the best-film award at the BAFTA's, Britain's equivalent of the Academy Awards.    Nicole Kidman was named best actr...
docs.lead_paragraph: Roman Polanski won as best director tonight and his film ''The Pianist,'' about a Jewish musician living in the Warsaw ghetto, won the best-film award at the BAFTA's, Britain's equivalent of the Academy Awards. Nicole Kidman was named best actress for her role as the tormented author Virginia Woolf in ''The Hours.'' Daniel Day-Lewis was named best actor for his chilling portrayal of a 19th-century gangster in Martin Scorsese's ''Gangs of New York.''
docs.abstract: Roman Polanski wins as best director and his film The Pianist wins best-film award at BAFTA's, Britain's equivalent of Academy Awards; Nicole Kidman is named best actress for her role in The Hours, and Daniel Day-Lewis is named best actor for his role in Gangs of New York (S)
